column1: '''Ladros''' was a highland region to the northeast of [[Dorthonion]]. It was held briefly as a fief by the [[House of Bëor]]
column2: but lost to [[Morgoth]] in the [[Dagor Bragollach]] ("Battle of Sudden Flame").

column1: The region of Ladros seems originally to have been a fief of [[Finrod|Finrod Felagund]] (at least
column2: his brothers [[Angrod]] and [[Aegnor]] held "the northern slopes of Dorthonion"<ref>{{S|Beleriand}}</ref>). Finrod later assigned this land to [[Boromir (Lord of Ladros)|Boromir]] of the House of Bëor
column3: whose members had long been loyal in his service. Boromir became [[Lord of Ladros]].

column2: there were three lords of Ladros — Boromir himself
column4: and Bregor's son [[Bregolas]]. In Bregolas' time
column5: Morgoth overwhelmed Dorthonion and Ladros in the [[Dagor Bragollach]]
column6: in which Bregolas himself was slain. His brother [[Barahir]] and [[Barahir's Outlaw Band|twelve faithful men]]
column7: became outlaws in their own land
column8: assaulting Morgoth's forces from their hidden lair at [[Tarn Aeluin]] on Ladros' southern borders. They were betrayed by [[Gorlim the Unhappy]]
column9: (who was himself deceived by Sauron into divulging the Outlaws' whereabouts.) and all were slain but [[Beren]]

column2: Ladros fell under the yoke of Morgoth until it was swallowed by the [[Belegaer|Great Sea]] at the end of the [[First Age]].
